10   Appendix 4 
PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The proposed Skills Development Project (SDP) will support the Nepalese workforce, 
including excluded groups, to develop their skills for domestic and international employment. To 
design the project, a participatory process involving all the relevant stakeholders is necessary to 
seek consensus on the scope, coverage and priority reforms to be supported by the project. The 
participatory process will be informed by an analysis of the technical education and vocational 
training (TEVT) subsector including its position and linkages with the labor market and general 
education  system.  The  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  will  assist  the 
Government and other key stakeholders in analyzing and prioritizing reforms and improvements 
to make the TEVT system more responsive to the needs of labor market as well as excluded 
groups Several initiatives, particularly the implementation of policy reforms supported by ADB‟s 
ongoing Skills for Employment (SEP) and other projects, have to be sustained to consolidate 
and institutionalize them.  
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The PPTA will (i) draw lessons learned from the ongoing projects and progress in TEVT 
subsector; (ii) update the subsector analysis; (iii) update labor market information; (iv) conduct a 
„gap‟ analysis; (v) identify economic sectors for demand oriented approach, with innovative 
partnership  arrangements;  (vi)  identify  strengthening  linkages  with  overseas  markets  (vii) 
identify institutional development and capacity development requirements in line with policy 
reforms; (viii) analyze governance risks in the sector and the executing and implementing 
agencies, and identify mitigating actions; and (ix) help other due diligence of the project. These 
inputs will be fed into a new project design.  
3.  The  PPTA  will  conduct  an  inception  workshop  at  the  initial  stage  to  inform  the 
stakeholders about the project preparation process and to agree on over direction of the new 
project in the form of draft design and monitoring framework, which will be adjusted and revised 
based on stakeholder feedback. The PPTA will conduct stakeholders‟ workshops and focus-
group discussions involving six types of stakeholders: (i) government policy makers and officials 
involved  in  implementation;  (ii)  private  sector  training  providers;  (iii)  teachers  and  teacher 
unions; (iv) students; (v) representatives from employers and employees; and (vi) academic and 
research institutions. 
4.  A major output of the TA will be a subsector analysis which can build on the previous 
analysis undertaken for the SEP and other recent projects to show progress made in recent 
years. The analysis will focus broadly on the organization of the TEVT subsector, institutional 
arrangements,  basic  information  and  trends  on  students,  teachers,  TEVT  institutions,  and 
performance  of  the  subsector  in  terms  of  equitable  access, quality  and  relevance,  overall 
responsiveness of TEVT system to labor market needs, employability and reforms achieved. 
Lessons learned from previous and ongoing projects, including SEP, will be included in the 
analysis. A full update on the current functioning of the skills testing and its usage by TEVT 
providers and its image and acceptance in the domestic and international labor market will be 
assessed. The PPTA will get a more detailed picture of the involvement of industry and other 
employers in developing TEVT at national and international/regional level, both in the private 
and the public sector. The sector analysis will also include a policy and institutional analysis of 
the TEVT subsector. The analysis is expected to review the by then approved policy framework 
and its consequences for the TEVT system and providers to meet Government priorities, and 
review the broader policy reforms in general education, in higher education, the investment 
climate and social security. Analysis of the role of overseas employment in the TEVT sector will

be included. The subsector analysis will also draw from the findings of the ongoing regional 
technical assistance that covers TEVT, good practices and lessons learned from national and 
international experiences (particularly from Sri Lanka, Australia, Malaysia, Singapore, South 
Korea) and experiences from within Nepal in PPP, market responsiveness and other good 
practices. 
5.  Another output of the PPTA is an analysis of the labor market to ascertain which skills 
are in demand, which courses are popular, the background of the TEVT students and the nature 
of underemployment, the overseas employment, and the skills shortage. This also includes an 
analysis of the social demand for the TEVT courses and their image, and the employability of 
graduates from different types of TEVT institutions and courses be it self-employment, informal 
employment, domestic employment or international employment. The analysis will also provide 
a wider view on the functioning of the labor market and identify any structural and or cultural 
barriers to employability or mismatch between supply and demand of skills. The analysis will 
look into prevailing gender patterns in the labor market to inform strategies for the project to 
respond to gender labor market segregation and provide women and men with wider range of 
decent employment choices through appropriate skills training to meet market needs. Based on 
this analysis the existing capacity to conduct labor market analysis will be assessed, and 
capacity and reforms for strengthened labor market analysis identified. 
6.  Based on the subsector analysis, including the lessons learned from SEP and other 
projects, and the labor market analysis, the PPTA will conduct an analysis of the requirement for 
short term training targeted at unskilled people and the trainings provided by ongoing projects 
and programs, specifically the Employment Fund and the World Bank‟s Skills Development 
project. This analysis is the basis for the type and scope of the short term trainings, and post 
training support for (self)employment and micro-credit, to be incorporated in the SDP. 
7.  The PPTA will identify economic sectors most suitable for a more demand oriented 
approach  for  providing  skills  development.  Possible  employment  opportunities  created  for 
different groups with different skills levels to strengthen the value chain in these sectors is part 
of this analysis and identification. This includes identifying potential linkages with overseas 
markets and identifying PPP opportunities for skills development in these sectors. In several 
sectors the private sector and other employers are well organized and are already providing 
skills training, like tourism, construction, and power. During the identification these initiatives will 
be further studied and options for further partnership developed. Partnerships can embrace 
major national and possibly international employers, who could be involved in the design of the 
training curriculum, and in industrial attachments. There will be performance–based contracts 
available  to  the  private  sector,  and  to  public-private  partnerships,  for  piloting  innovative 
(including non-institutional) delivery modalities such as flexible approaches to apprenticeships 
and apprenticeship management, the implementation of workplace arrangements to recognize 
prior learning, or current competencies, acquired through informal learning (and providing gap-
filling training as required), and also for structured workplace skills acquisition leading to formal 
assessment and certification. Where appropriate, these PPPs will include involvement from 
micro-service credit providers to help interested participants in training programs to access 
credit to start their own small businesses. After identification of the first economic sector, a 
specialist for this sector will be recruited to assist the PPTA-team. 
8.  The PPTA will identify institutional development and capacity development requirements 
in line with policy reforms. These will focus on requirements in the TEVT sector, especially with 
an expected shift in the role of the government. The government will focus more on facilitation 
and regulation, while autonomous bodies, universities and other institutions, and the private 
sector will focus more on service delivery  in  PPP arrangements. The exact nature of the 
requirements will depend on the approved policy framework. Analysis of the required capacity to

develop and implement the NVQF and related skills testing, to develop and implement the 
TEVT-fund board, and its relation with existing funds like the Employment Fund and proposed 
funds like the social security fund, and to develop the public and private providers, including a 
private training providers association, is part of this exercise. Ensuring that no duplication will 
occur  requires  an  overview  of  the  support  provided  and  planned  by  other  projects  and 
development partners in these areas. The requirement will also focus on the position of the 
TEVT-sector in the education sector and in its linkages with the economic development. Labor 
market information analysis is one of the core requirements.  
9.  The PPTA will analyze governance (PFM, procurement and corruption), and institutional 
risks in the sector and the executing and implementing agencies, and identify mitigating actions. 
The PPTA will update the economic and financial analysis undertaken for SEP, with special 
focus on sustainability, alternatives considered, economic internal rate of return, and poverty 
analysis. Finally, the PPTA will help the Government to formulate the Project for review by the 
Government and ADB. In doing this, the TA will also ensure social analysis and safeguards 
issues. Given the limited knowledge about the impact of current TEVT interventions an impact 
analysis will be part of the Project. It is crucial that the design is the result of a participatory 
process. A summary of expected outputs and expected time line are provided in Table A4.1.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangements 
10.  The  Government  of  Nepal  has  requested  ADB  to  finance  the  PPTA  for  $500,000 
equivalent on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, administered by ADB. 
The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2. The government will provide in-kind

contribution including staff time, office space and other logistical support. The Government is 
advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to financing any ensuing project.

D.  Staff Time Requirement 
11.  The project processing team (estimated time required) includes Social Sector Specialist, 
SAHS (7 weeks); Senior Social Sector Specialist, SAHS (7 weeks); Associate Project Officer, 
NRM  (5  weeks);  Senior  Public  Management  Specialist,  RSGP (5  weeks);  Lead  Education 
Specialist,  SAHS  (2  weeks);  Social  Development  Officer  (Gender),  NRM  (2  weeks); 
Environment  Officer,  NRM  (2  weeks);  Social  Development  Officer  (Safeguards),  NRM  (2 
weeks); Peace and Conflict Officer, NRM (2 weeks); Procurement Officer, NRM (2 weeks); and 
Economics Officers, NRM (2 weeks). 
 
E.  Consulting Services 
12.  The  PPTA  will  be  implemented  over  a  period  of  6  months  from  the  fielding  of 
consultants, which is anticipated in March 2012. ADB will recruit a team of consultants through a 
firm using simplified technical proposal for the quality- and cost-based selection method (quality-
cost ratio of 80:20) as well as on an individual basis in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will provide 12 person-
months of international (2 person-months on individual basis) and 27 person-months of national 
(3  person-months  on  individual  basis)  consulting  services  in  TEVT  policy  and  planning, 
management and institutional arrangements, TEVT industry relations, value chain and labor 
market  analysis,  TEVT  financing,  fiduciary  risk  assessment,  financial  management, 
procurement,  environment,  gender  and  social  development,  etc.  A  pool  of  consultants  is 
included to exercise flexibility to expedite the process, to meet the Government‟s requirements,

F.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The Ministry of Education will be the executing agency (EA) for the PPTA. A PPTA 
steering committee will be established with the secretary of MoE as the chairperson, and with 
representatives from Ministry of Finance, Planning Commission, CTEVT, Ministry of Labor, 
Ministry of Industry, Ministry of Tourism, and representation from the private sector via the 
Federation of Nepal Chambers of Commerce and Industries and the Confederation of Nepal 
Industries, to ensure coordination with concerned departments and institutions and to provide 
overall guidance to the PPTA on policies and reforms. A technical committee with experts from 
the key stakeholders, under guidance from the CTEVT, will be established to guide technical 
aspects of the design. While the steering committee will meet 2-3 times during the PPTA 
implementation, the technical committee will meet regularly to guide and monitor progress and 
ensure effective design of the SDP.
